__data__.text: Central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria are located in a region where three tectonic plates meet: the African, Arabian, and Anatolian Plates. This tectonic setting influences the geology of the area.

In central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria, the meeting of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian Plates influences the region's geology. The boundary between the African and Arabian Plates is characterized by the Dead Sea Transform (DST), a significant left-lateral strike-slip fault that facilitates the northward movement of Arabia relative to Africa.

In the same region, the Dead Sea Transform (DST) fault, which marks the boundary between the African and Arabian Plates and enables the northward drift of Arabia in relation to Africa, terminates at the East Anatolian Fault (EAF). The EAF is a significant left-lateral strike-slip fault zone that allows for the westward motion of the Anatolian Plate, which is being pushed in that direction by the northward movement of the Arabian Plate.

The Dead Sea Transform (DST) and East Anatolian Fault (EAF) intersect at the Marash Triple Junction, where the EAF extends further west, functioning as the boundary between the African and Anatolian Plates, ultimately connecting to the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge.

The East Anatolian Fault (EAF) measures 700 km (430 mi) and is divided into seven segments, named, in order from the northeast: Karlıova, Ilıca, Palu, Pütürge, Erkenek, Pazarcık, and Amanos. This fault continues westward, serving as the boundary between the African and Anatolian Plates, and is connected to the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge.

The Pazarcık and Amanos segments are two parts of the seven-segmented East Anatolian Fault (EAF), which spans 700 km (430 mi) and serves as the boundary between the African and Anatolian Plates. The Amanos segment is sometimes classified as part of the Dead Sea Transform (DST) or viewed as a transitional structure between the EAF and DST.

In addition to the seven main sections, the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) includes a northern branch, which consists of segments such as Sürgü, Çardak, Savrun, Çokak, Toprakkale, Yumurtalık, Karataş, Yakapınar, and Düziçi–İskenderun. Sometimes, the Amanos segment is considered to be a continuation of the Dead Sea Transform (DST) or a transition zone between the EAF and DST.

The slip rate along the primary part of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) system reduces as one moves southwestward, going from 10 mm/year on the Karlıova segment to 2.9 mm/year on the Amanos segment, which might be part of the Dead Sea Transform (DST) or a transitional zone between the EAF and DST.

In the northern section of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) system, the Çardak segment has a slip rate of approximately 2.5 mm/year. The Sürgü-Çardak Fault, which runs parallel to the EAF, is an east-west striking fault that spans 160 km in length. This information suggests that the Sürgü-Çardak Fault could be a distinct feature from the EAF or a transition zone connected to the Dead Sea Transform (DST).

The Sürgü-Çardak Fault is divided into two segments: the 70 km (43 mi) long Sürgü Fault, stretching from Çelikhan to Nurhak, and the 90 km (56 mi) long Çardak Fault, extending from Nurhak to Göksun. This description supports the idea that the Sürgü-Çardak Fault might be a separate feature from the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) or a transitional zone linked to the Dead Sea Transform (DST).

The Sürgü-Çardak Fault consists of two segments, the 70 km long Sürgü Fault and the 90 km long Çardak Fault, which might be a distinct entity from the East Anatolian Fault or a part of the Dead Sea Transform. Seismic activity on the Sürgü-Çardak Fault is minimal, with only one recorded earthquake, a M 6.8 event in 1544. There is some debate among scientists about which faults belong to the northern part of the Dead Sea Transform and which to the East Anatolian Fault.

The Sürgü-Çardak Fault's northernmost section, comprising the 70 km Sürgü Fault and 90 km Çardak Fault, has experienced minimal seismic activity, with only one known earthquake in 1544. Researchers are uncertain whether this fault connects to the East Anatolian Fault or the Dead Sea Transform's northern part.
